4.text:
Every few years the El Niño phenomenon
kicks into life in the Pacific Ocean

8.text:
around the equator. It can affect weather
around the world

13.text: changing the odds of floods, drought, heatwaves

16.text:
and cold seasons for different regions
even raising global temperatures.

21.text:
But what is El Niño and how does it
happen?

24.text:
Firstly we need to know what's normally
happening in the tropical Pacific.

29.text: This vast stretch of ocean sees consistent winds

33.text:
called 'trade winds' that blow from east to
west.

36.text:
These winds push warm water near the
surface

40.text:
in their direction of travel, so the warm
water piles

43.text: up on the western side of the ocean around Asia and Australasia

47.text:
On the other side of the ocean around
South and Central America

51.text:
as the warmer water gets pushed away
from the coast

55.text:
it's replaced by cold water which is
pulled up from deeper down in the ocean

60.text:
a process called upwelling. This creates
a temperature difference

65.text:
across the tropical Pacific with warmer
water piled up in the West

69.text:
and cooler water in the east. Warmer
water

73.text:
adds extra heat to the air which causes
the air to rise with more vigor

77.text:
and its this rising air that creates an
area of more

81.text:
unsettled weather with more cloud in
rainfall

84.text: That rising air in the West

87.text:
sets up atmospheric circulation across
this part of the world

91.text:
with warm moist air rising on one side
of the Ocean

94.text: and cooler dryer air descending on the other

98.text:
This circulation reinforces the easterly
winds

102.text:
so this part of the world sits in a
self-perpetuating state

106.text:
until El Niño begins. If conditions are
right

111.text:
tropical Pacific weather systems or slow
changes in the ocean around the equator

116.text: can set off a chain of events which weaken or even reverse the usual trade winds

122.text:
With weakened trade winds there's less
push

125.text: of warm surface water to the western side

128.text:
of the ocean and less upwelling of cold
water

131.text:
on the eastern side. This allows the
usually colder parts of the ocean to warm

137.text:
canceling out the normal temperature
difference.

140.text: Because the area of warmest water moves

143.text:
so does the associated wet and unsettled
weather.

146.text:
This changes rainfall patterns over
the

150.text:
equatorial Pacific as well as the
large-scale wind

154.text:
patterns. It's this change in winds which
has a knock-on effect

158.text:
changing temperature and rainfall in
locations

161.text: around the world. The main impacts

164.text:
are around the tropics where you see an
increase in the risk of floods

168.text: in Peru and droughts in Indonesia, India

171.text:
and parts of Brazil. But virtually
wherever you are in the world

176.text:
El Niño has the potential to affect you
directly

179.text:
via the weather or indirectly via
socio-economic impacts

184.text:
There's another impact from El Niño
which happens because of

188.text:
all the extra heat at the surface of the
tropical Pacific.

191.text: This releases vast amounts of energy

194.text: into the atmosphere which can temporarily push up global temperatures.

199.text: This is why El Niño years often feature

202.text: among the warmest on record. Each El Niño event

206.text:
is different so the global impacts can
change.

210.text:
You can find out more about the
different impacts of El Niño

213.text:
on our website. El Niño peaks around
Christmas-time

217.text:
and last for several months. It can dive
back to neutral conditions

221.text: but sometimes reverses into La Niña.

226.text:
This is the flip side of the
oscillation which sees

230.text:
a strengthening of the normal trade
winds.

233.text:
This pushes the warmest water to the far
western part of the tropical Pacific

238.text:
and increases the upwelling of cold
water

241.text: in the east. This cooler water

244.text:
extends out from the coast of the
Americas towards the central part of the ocean

249.text: La Niña also impacts global weather

252.text: and tends to have opposite effects to El Niño.

255.text:
You can also see more about La Niña and
its impacts
